name: Adobo
description: A popular Filipino dish made with marinated meat simmered in soy sauce, vinegar, and garlic.
instructions: 1. Marinate meat in soy sauce, garlic, and peppercorns for at least 30 minutes.
2. Sauté garlic until golden brown.
3. Add marinated meat, bay leaves, and vinegar to the pot.
4. Simmer with water until the meat is tender and the sauce reduces.
5. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot.

name: Sinigang na Baboy
description: A sour pork soup with tamarind, vegetables, and green chilies, perfect for a rainy day.
instructions: 1. Boil pork with onion and tomatoes until the meat is tender.
2. Add tamarind mix and simmer for another 5 minutes.
3. Add the eggplants and green chilies and continue cooking until the vegetables are soft.
4. Stir in the kangkong and cook for another 2 minutes.
5. Season with salt and serve hot.

name: Kare-Kare
description: A rich, savory stew made with oxtail and vegetables in a creamy peanut sauce.
instructions: 1. Boil oxtail until tender, skimming off any scum.
2. Add vegetables like banana heart, eggplant, and string beans to the pot.
3. Stir in peanut butter and annatto water.
4. Thicken the sauce with rice flour dissolved in water.
5. Season with salt and pepper. Serve with bagoong.

name: Pancit Canton
description: Stir-fried noodles mixed with chicken and vegetables in a flavorful soy-based sauce.
instructions: 1. Sauté onion and chicken breast until cooked.
2. Add carrots, cabbage, and snow peas to the pan.
3. Pour in soy sauce and water, stirring until vegetables are tender.
4. Add the canton noodles and toss until well coated with sauce.
5. Cook for another 2-3 minutes. Serve hot.

name: Lechon Kawali
description: Crispy deep-fried pork belly, often served with a side of liver sauce or vinegar.
instructions: 1. Boil pork belly with garlic, salt, and peppercorns until tender.
2. Let the pork cool and dry for several hours or overnight.
3. Heat oil in a deep pan and fry the pork belly until crispy.
4. Remove from oil and let drain on paper towels.
5. Serve with lechon sauce or vinegar dip.

name: Chicken Inasal
description: A flavorful grilled chicken marinated in vinegar, calamansi, and garlic, basted with annatto oil.
instructions: 1. Marinate chicken in calamansi juice, vinegar, garlic, salt, and pepper for at least 2 hours.
2. Preheat the grill.
3. Grill the chicken, basting with annatto oil until cooked through.
4. Turn the chicken occasionally to ensure even cooking.
5. Serve hot with garlic rice.

name: Laing
description: A spicy dish made of dried taro leaves simmered in rich coconut milk with chilies.
instructions: 1. Sauté garlic and ginger until fragrant.
2. Add pork and cook until lightly browned.
3. Pour in coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
4. Add taro leaves and chilies, stirring occasionally.
5. Simmer until taro leaves are tender and the sauce thickens.

name: Bicol Express
description: A spicy, creamy dish made with pork and chilies cooked in coconut milk and shrimp paste.
instructions: 1. Sauté garlic and shrimp paste in a pan until fragrant.
2. Add pork belly and cook until lightly browned.
3. Pour in coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
4. Add green chilies and continue cooking until pork is tender.
5. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

name: Bulalo
description: A comforting beef shank soup simmered with bone marrow, corn, and leafy greens.
instructions: 1. Boil beef shank with onion until tender, skimming off scum as needed.
2. Add corn and potatoes to the pot and continue simmering.
3. Once the vegetables are cooked, add pechay.
4. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
5. Serve hot with rice.

name: Tinola
description: A light chicken soup with green papaya and malunggay, flavored with ginger and fish sauce.
instructions: 1. Sauté ginger, garlic, and onion in a pot.
2. Add the chicken pieces and cook until lightly browned.
3. Pour in water and bring to a simmer.
4. Add the green papaya and cook until tender.
5. Stir in malunggay leaves and season with fish sauce.

name: Lumpiang Shanghai
description: Deep-fried spring rolls filled with ground pork and vegetables, often served with sweet and sour sauce.
instructions: 1. Mix ground pork, carrot, onion, egg, salt, and pepper in a bowl.
2. Place a spoonful of the mixture on a spring roll wrapper and roll tightly.
3. Heat oil in a pan and deep fry the rolls until golden brown.
4. Drain on paper towels and serve with sweet and sour sauce.

name: Puto
description: A traditional Filipino steamed rice cake, often topped with cheese or salted egg.
ingredients: Cheese or salted egg for topping
instructions: 1. Mix rice flour, water, sugar, and baking powder into a smooth batter.
2. Pour the batter into small molds and top with cheese or salted egg.
3. Steam for about 20 minutes or until cooked through.
4. Let cool before serving.

name: Ginataang Gulay
description: A creamy vegetable dish cooked in coconut milk, often with squash, string beans, and eggplant.
instructions: 1. Sauté garlic in a pan until golden.
2. Add coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
3. Add squash, string beans, and eggplant, and cook until tender.
4. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

name: Sisig
description: A sizzling dish made from chopped pig's face, liver, and ears, seasoned with calamansi, soy sauce, and chilies.
instructions: 1. Boil pig’s face and ears until tender, then chop into small pieces.
2. Sauté garlic and onion in a pan.
3. Add chopped pig's face, liver, and ears, and cook until crispy.
4. Season with soy sauce, calamansi juice, and chilies.
5. Serve on a sizzling plate.

name: Pinakbet
description: A vegetable stew made with shrimp paste, squash, bitter melon, eggplant, and string beans.
instructions: 1. Sauté garlic in a pan until fragrant.
2. Add shrimp paste and sauté briefly.
3. Add squash, eggplant, bitter melon, and string beans.
4. Simmer until vegetables are tender.

name: Taho
description: A warm snack of silken tofu topped with sweet syrup and tapioca pearls.
instructions: 1. Boil tapioca pearls until soft, then drain and set aside.
2. Dissolve brown sugar in water to make syrup.
3. Steam silken tofu until warmed through.
4. Serve tofu in cups, topped with tapioca pearls and syrup.

name: Palabok
description: A savory noodle dish topped with shrimp sauce, chicharrón, and hard-boiled eggs.
instructions: 1. Cook rice noodles according to package instructions and set aside.
2. Sauté garlic and shrimp in a pan, then add annatto water.
3. Pour shrimp sauce over noodles.
4. Top with chicharrón, eggs, and green onions.

name: Arroz Caldo
description: A comforting rice porridge with chicken, garlic, and ginger, often topped with boiled eggs.
instructions: 1. Sauté garlic and ginger in a pot.
2. Add chicken and cook until lightly browned.
3. Stir in rice and water, and bring to a simmer.
4. Cook until rice is soft and porridge-like.
5. Season with salt and pepper, and top with boiled eggs.

name: Dinuguan
description: A savory stew made from pork and pig's blood, seasoned with vinegar and chilies.
instructions: 1. Sauté garlic and onion in a pan.
2. Add pork and cook until browned.
3. Stir in vinegar and simmer until pork is tender.
4. Add pig’s blood and chilies, and cook until sauce thickens.

name: Halo-Halo
description: A popular Filipino dessert with layers of sweetened fruits, beans, shaved ice, and leche flan.
instructions: 1. Layer ingredients in a tall glass.
2. Top with crushed ice, leche flan, and evaporated milk.
3. Sweeten with sugar and serve.
